questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} x^2-1, & x<2 \\ 3x-4, & x>2 \end{cases}$, $f(2)=0$. At $x=2$:
questions.explanation: Left limit: $2^2-1=3$, Right limit: $3(2)-4=2$, f(2)=0. Limits exist but differ → jump discontinuity

questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} x+1, & x<1 \\ x^2, & x>1 \end{cases}$, $f(1)=2$. At $x=1$:
questions.explanation: Left limit: $1+1=2$, Right limit: $1^2=1$, f(1)=2. Limits unequal → jump discontinuity (not continuous)

questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} x^2, & x<1 \\ 3x-1, & x>1 \end{cases}$, $f(1)=1$. At $x=1$:
questions.explanation: Left limit: $1^2=1$, Right limit: $3(1)-1=2$, f(1)=1. Limits unequal → jump discontinuity

questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} x+4, & x<0 \\ x^2, & x>0 \end{cases}$, $f(0)=4$. At $x=0$:
questions.explanation: Left limit: $0+4=4$, Right limit: $0^2=0$, f(0)=4. Limits exist but differ → jump discontinuity

questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} x^2, & x<2 \\ kx+1, & x>2 \end{cases}$, $f(2)=5$. Find $k$ for continuity.
questions.explanation: Left limit: $2^2=4$, Right limit: $2k+1$. For continuity: $4=2k+1=5$ → $2k+1=5$ → $k=2$

questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} 2x-3, & x<1 \\ x^2-1, & x>1 \end{cases}$, $f(1)=0$. At $x=1$:
questions.explanation: Left limit: $2(1)-3=-1$, Right limit: $1^2-1=0$, f(1)=0. Limits unequal → jump discontinuity

questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} x^3, & x<1 \\ x+1, & x>1 \end{cases}$, $f(1)=2$. At $x=1$:
questions.explanation: Left limit: $1^3=1$, Right limit: $1+1=2$, f(1)=2. Limits unequal → jump discontinuity

questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} x^2-1, & x<3 \\ 2x-4, & x>3 \end{cases}$, $f(3)=5$. At $x=3$:
questions.explanation: Left limit: $3^2-1=8$, Right limit: $2(3)-4=2$, f(3)=5. All different → jump discontinuity

questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} 3x-1, & x<2 \\ x^2-3, & x>2 \end{cases}$, $f(2)=5$. At $x=2$:
questions.explanation: Left limit: $3(2)-1=5$, Right limit: $2^2-3=1$, f(2)=5. Limits unequal → jump discontinuity

questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} x^2, & x<1 \\ kx+1, & x>1 \end{cases}$, $f(1)=2$. Find $k$.
questions.explanation: Left limit: $1^2=1$, For continuity: $1=k(1)+1=2$ → $k+1=2$ → $k=1$

questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} 4x-3, & x<1 \\ x^2+k, & x>1 \end{cases}$, $f(1)=1$. Continuity requires $k=$:
questions.explanation: Left limit: $4(1)-3=1$, Right limit: $1^2+k=1+k$. Set equal: $1=1+k$ → $k=0$

questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} x+1, & x<0 \\ x^2, & x>0 \end{cases}$, $f(0)=0$. At $x=0$:
questions.explanation: Left limit: $0+1=1$, Right limit: $0^2=0$, f(0)=0. Limits exist but differ → jump discontinuity

questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} x^2-2x, & x<2 \\ kx+4, & x>2 \end{cases}$, $f(2)=0$. Find $k$ for continuity.
questions.explanation: Left limit: $2^2-2(2)=0$, Right limit: $2k+4$. Set equal: $0=2k+4$ → $k=-2$

questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} x^2-9, & x<3 \\ 6x-k, & x>3 \end{cases}$, $f(3)=0$. For continuity, $k=$:
questions.explanation: Left limit: $3^2-9=0$, Right limit: $6(3)-k=18-k$. Set equal: $0=18-k$ → $k=18$

questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} x+5, & x<1 \\ x^2-3, & x>1 \end{cases}$, $f(1)=2$. At $x=1$:
questions.explanation: Left limit: $1+5=6$, Right limit: $1^2-3=-2$, f(1)=2. Limits unequal → jump discontinuity

questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} 2x-1, & x<2 \\ 3x-4, & x>2 \end{cases}$, $f(2)=0$. At $x=2$:
questions.explanation: Left limit: $2(2)-1=3$, Right limit: $3(2)-4=2$, f(2)=0. Limits exist but differ → jump discontinuity

questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} x^2, & x<2 \\ 4x-k, & x>2 \end{cases}$, $f(2)=4$. For continuity, $k=$:
questions.explanation: Left limit: $2^2=4$, Right limit: $4(2)-k=8-k$. Set equal: $4=8-k$ → $k=4$

questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} x^2-1, & x<1 \\ 2x-k, & x>1 \end{cases}$, $f(1)=1$. For continuity, $k=$:
questions.explanation: Left limit: $1^2-1=0$, Right limit: $2(1)-k=2-k$. Set equal: $0=2-k$ → $k=2$

questions.question: $f(x) = \begin{cases} x^2-4x, & x<3 \\ kx-3, & x>3 \end{cases}$, $f(3)=-3$. Find $k$.
questions.explanation: Left limit: $3^2-4(3)=-3$, Right limit: $3k-3$. Set equal: $-3=3k-3$ → $3k=0$ → $k=0$
